description:
Apodemus speciosus, commonly known as the Japanese wood mouse, is a species of rodent belonging to the genus Apodemus. It is found in Japan, including the main islands of Honshu, Shikoku, and Kyushu, as well as on some smaller islands.

The Japanese wood mouse is a small to medium-sized rodent, typically measuring between 10-15 cm in length, including the tail. It has a robust and compact body, with a rounded head, large eyes, and prominent ears. The fur is usually reddish-brown or grayish-brown on the upper parts, with a lighter, more grayish or whitish underside. The tail is well-furred and slightly shorter than the head and body length.

Apodemus speciosus is an arboreal and nocturnal species, primarily inhabiting forested areas, including deciduous and coniferous forests, as well as urban and suburban environments. It is an opportunistic omnivore, feeding on a variety of plant materials, such as seeds, fruits, and nuts, as well as small invertebrates.

The Japanese wood mouse is an important component of the ecosystem, serving as a prey species for various predators, including birds of prey, snakes, and small carnivores. It also plays a role in seed dispersal and forest regeneration through its foraging and burrowing activities.

This species is generally considered of Least Concern on the IUCN Red List, as it is widespread and abundant throughout its native range in Japan. However, local population declines may occur due to habitat loss, fragmentation, and human-wildlife conflicts.
